---
title: "Posts that include executable code"
date: "2025-02-12"
categories: [quarto, dotfiles]
jupyter: python3
---








## Executing code with quarto

Quarto makes it easy to include executable code within documents. For example:

Including
````md
```python
for i in range(5):
    print(i)
```
````

Produces:

::: {.cell execution_count=1}
``` {.python .cell-code}
for i in range(5):
    print(i)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
0
1
2
3
4
```
:::
:::


---

The output of the code is executed and included in the document.

See the [Quarto documentation](https://quarto.org/docs/computations/python.html) for more examples.

For example, including figures is a really nice feature.

### Matplotlib

::: {.cell execution_count=2}
``` {.python .cell-code}
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
y = np.sin(x)

plt.plot(x, y)
plt.xlabel('x')
plt.ylabel('sin(x)')
plt.title('A simple plot')
plt.show()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display}
![A caption can even be included](index_files/figure-pdf/fig-example-output-1.pdf){#fig-example fig-pos='H'}
:::
:::


### Plotly

And it work with plotly too!

::: {#fig-plotly .cell execution_count=3}
``` {.python .cell-code}
import plotly.express as px

df = px.data.iris()
fig = px.scatter(df, x="sepal_width", y="sepal_length", 
                 color="species", 
                 marginal_y="violin", marginal_x="box", 
                 trendline="ols", template="simple_white")
fig.show()
```

::: {#fig-plotly-1 .cell-output .cell-output-display}
```
Unable to display output for mime type(s): text/html
```

Using plotly instead of matplotlib
:::

::: {#fig-plotly-2 .cell-output .cell-output-display}
```
Unable to display output for mime type(s): text/html
```
:::
:::
